metadata.title: Solar geoengineering could redistribute malaria risk in developing countries

affiliation.laboratory: Quantitative Disease Ecology and Conservation (QDEC) Lab Group

abstract.text: Solar geoengineering is often framed as a stopgap measure to decrease the magnitude, impacts, and injustice 29 of climate change. However, the costs or benefits of geoengineering for human health are largely unknown.
We project how geoengineering could impact malaria risk by comparing transmission suitability and 31
populations-at-risk today against moderate and high emissions scenarios (RCP 4.5 and 8.5) with and 32

without geoengineering over the next half-century. We show that if geoengineering deployment cools the 33 tropics, it could help protect high elevation populations in eastern Africa from the encroachment of malaria, 34 but could increase transmission in lowland sub-Saharan Africa and southern Asia. Compared to extreme 35

warming, we also find that by 2070, geoengineering would nullify a projected reduction of nearly one 36 billion people at risk of malaria. Our results indicate that geoengineering strategies designed to offset 37
warming are not guaranteed to unilaterally improve health outcomes, and could produce regional trade-offs 38
among Global South countries that are often excluded from geoengineering conversations.

body_text.text: considered. 48 Among these proposed radical schemes is solar geoengineering (also called solar radiation 49 modification, or SRM), whereby the deliberate injection of aerosols into the stratosphere could 50 reflect a small amount of sunlight back to space, cooling Earth. SRM has never been tested 51 outdoors, but large volcanic eruptions are evidence that increasing stratospheric aerosols would 52 cool the planet (2,3). While responses of temperature and precipitation to SRM have been studied 53 in detail, very little is known about possible consequences for humans or ecosystems (4,5). 54 Although there is high confidence in the adverse impacts of global warming-and therefore, 55 motivation to avoid unmitigated warming-the climate of a world with SRM would still differ in 56 notable ways from the current or preindustrial climates. As a result, there is no a priori reason to 57 think that geoengineering would necessarily improve health outcomes uniformly across regions or 58 health burdens. One study has examined the potential impact of SRM on skin cancer and pollution-59 related illness (6), while another has explored health impacts of urban heat stress (7). However, 60 very little is known about possible impacts on infectious diseases, which account for a much higher 61 proportion of global mortality (especially in low-and middle-income countries). This constitutes 62 a major research gap (8), especially given increased attention on SRM and the critical need to 63 consider risks to health in policymaking on climate change.

Of all the possible infectious diseases to prioritize for health impact assessments, many of the best 65 candidates are vector-borne diseases, given their massive global burden and their well-66 demonstrated (and easily forecasted) climate linkage. Pathogens transmitted by arthropod vectors 67 like mosquitoes or ticks are particularly sensitive to temperature, which determines both their rate 68 of replication in hosts, and the activity and metabolism of their ectothermic (cold-blooded) vectors. 69 Together, these produce a pattern where their transmission responds unimodally to temperature, 70 in a roughly Gaussian response curve (9). Thanks to recent advances in experimental and modeling 71 approaches, scientists can rapidly evaluate these response functions, and confidently identify 72 thermal optima (Topt) and outer limits of transmission (Tmin and Tmax). Using these parameters, Thanks to these approaches, an emerging body of evidence shows a high confidence link between 80 global climate change and a potential resurgence of vector-borne diseases. By 2070, climate 81 change is expected to increase the global population at risk of the Aedes mosquito-borne dengue 82 . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted October 25, 2020. countries agreeing on an optimal amount of geoengineering. We selected the G3 and GLENS 134 scenarios because they simulate the more "realistic" creation of a stratospheric aerosol layer, 135 deploy geoengineering within emissions scenarios widely used in climate impact assessments, and 136 differ in their injection strategies in tropical regions where the burden of malaria is highest. Other 137 scenarios were not used due to potential layers of additional impacts on malaria that might require 138 dedicated attention (e.g., the potential for termination shocks in the G4 scenario, which might 139 interact with how population immunity changes on the timescale of decades, with complex impacts 140 on disease transmission). 141 We use these scenarios to predict the transmission boundaries and intensity of falciparum and 142 vivax malaria in their respective regions, and project their shifting transmission and seasonality 143 over the next half-century (2020 to 2070). We limit our analyses to Africa, Asia, and Latin 144 America, where malaria is endemic today, as a subset of the total global shift in favorable 145 temperatures to higher latitudes that has been well-documented for tropical vector-borne diseases.

body_text.text: While temperatures may become more favorable for malaria transmission at higher latitudes, This approach cannot necessarily predict total incidence, because major factors such as population 165 density, malaria control, or elimination progress are not included. However, mapping R0(T) can be 166 a first-order proxy of transmission suitability, and, by comparing between scenarios, can indicate 167 where the intensity of transmission and the potential resulting burden of malaria would be higher 168 or lower in different pathways. We make two such comparisons: first, we compare possible futures 169 . However, we identified several major differences in transmission suitability, which 174 were more pronounced when geoengineering is used to offset warming from RCP 8.5, the high 175 emissions scenario (Figure 2 ). Compared to climate change without solar geoengineering, we To approximate these relative burdens, we calculated population at risk from stable and unstable 209 transmission in these areas, using future population projections based on the shared socioeconomic 210 pathways paired with our climate scenarios (SSP2-RCP 4.5 and SSP5-RCP 8.5; see Methods).

body_text.text: In climate change scenarios without geoengineering, much of the world faces increased malaria 212 risk over at least the next decade; in the longer term, regional redistributions of both falciparum 213 and vivax malaria risk are expected throughout the tropics, on the order of hundreds of millions of 214 people. For both RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5, substantial increases in populations at risk from malaria 215 are projected in east Africa and to a lesser degree central Africa, particularly in high elevation 216 regions where colder temperatures have previously limited malaria transmission. In west Africa, 217 malaria risk also increases, but is dependent on the amount of warming; in RCP 8.5, population 218 exposed to stable transmission risk peaks mid-century and then declines, as much of the region 219 becomes too warm. South and southeast Asia show a similar trend, where warming temperatures 220 in RCP 8.5 lead to massive declines in population at risk (~200 million people in each region), 221 including some populations shifting from stable into unstable risk. In the rest of the tropics, 222 warming temperatures lead to little change or mild declines in total risk, again with shifts from 223 stable to unstable transmission risk. 224 We find that solar geoengineering to stabilize planetary temperatures at 2020 levels despite 225 moderate greenhouse gas emissions (the G3 scenario) is projected to initially mitigate population 226 at risk of malaria very slightly, but this effect is short-lived and uncertain, and the total population 227 at risk converges on climate change without geoengineering (RCP 4.5) by mid-century (Figure 3) . 228 This largely holds across regions (Extended Data Figures 1 and 2) ; the most pronounced (Figure 3) . We also find strong regional patterns for these projected impacts. For Finally, we observed that uncertainty about both baseline climate change impacts and 249 geoengineering impacts showed a tremendous degree of regional variation, which was largely 250 consistent between mid-and high-emissions scenarios. In Latin America and central Africa, 251 changes were highly consistent across climate model runs, and differences between scenarios were 252 minimal. In east and west Africa, we found that differences between climate scenarios were 253 pronounced, but again largely consistent across runs by the end of the century. However, we found 254 that southern Asia-a hotspot of projected changes, and the global hotspot of vivax malaria 255 . This likely reflects a combination 258 of climate model uncertainty and highly aggregated populations, where any one pixel's suitability 259 for malaria may have a marked impact on the total population at risk. warming is projected to increase risk, our results show that case by case assessment is urgently 281 needed, and regional differences in outcomes must be disaggregated. Without specific research, 282 assumptions that solar geoengineering's health impacts would be intrinsically fair and effective 283 are unsupported, even compared to the most extreme scenarios for climate change. Emissions 284 reduction for climate change mitigation is widely agreed to produce major net benefits across the 285 health sector; climate geoengineering strategies will likely not be as easily weighed, and may be is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted October 25, 2020. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.10.21.20217257 doi: medRxiv preprint willpower. After COVID-19, the burden of malaria -and many other infectious diseases that have 299 been the subject of large-scale elimination programs -hangs in the balance. Even if COVID-19 is 300 eventually contained, most countries' health systems will remain weakened, and some will face a 301 resurgence of diseases that were well-controlled or even nearing elimination before interventions 302 were disrupted (39-41). In a world that eliminates COVID-19, "builds back better," and recoups 303 these losses, malaria transmission might not be an important issue for climate policy. In a world 304 that fails to do so, with lasting damage from the pandemic, malaria might still be one of the biggest 305 climate related priorities for developing countries, and therefore, one of the greatest potential 306 downsides (or negative repercussions) of solar geoengineering.

To estimate future populations at risk, we paired representative concentration pathways (RCPs) 444 with shared socioeconomic pathways (SSPs) using the conventional scenario matrix, which To project populations-at-risk from malaria, we rasterized region boundaries (using a fractional 455 approach to proportional area, rounded to the nearest 1% of a grid cell), and then summed the 456 populations in every grid cell that fell within thermal bounds and precipitation cutoffs.

Temperature cutoffs were applied at the daily level and summarized for each pixel, and classified 458 . FIGREF0.text: 73 modelers can identify when climatic conditions fall within the boundaries of transmission, and 74 evaluate how the seasonal window of transmission would change in a warming climate (10,11). In 75 the best-quantified cases, temperature can even be explicitly linked to the basic rate of reproduction 76 R0(T), which quantifies the per-infection ability of the pathogen to transmit onwards; projections 77 of R0(T) under different climate scenarios can be used to infer whether particular conditions would 78 support epidemic or endemic transmission.

FIGREF3.text: We test this idea by investigating scenarios where solar geoengineering is deployed to stabilize123 average global temperature at 2020 levels against a background of moderate (representative 124 concentration pathway, or RCP, 4.5) or high future emissions (RCP 8.5), and compare this to 125 global warming for the same emissions scenarios without geoengineering. In the Geoengineering 2020 levels, but does this at four locations (30°N, 30°S, 15°N and 15°S) in order 131 to reduce over-cooling of the tropics. Geoengineering could be deployed to offset either all or some 132 amount of global warming, and experts on climate politics and policy have noted the challenge of 133

FIGREF4.text: 147 healthcare systems in the United States, Europe, and Australia are likely to be strong enough to 148 prevent sporadic importations from establishing malaria transmission in these regions. In contrast, 149 developing countries face the greatest burdens of vector-borne disease, both at present and-with 150 the additional strain of climate change on healthcare systems-in the future.

FIGREF5.text: an approach based on the temperature-dependent basic reproduction number R0(T), which 153 has become popular as the thermal biology of mosquito-borne disease has become better 154 understood (9,29). Because arthropod vectors are ectothermic, the processes of mosquito life 155 history and pathogen transmission are very sensitive to temperature, following a simple unimodal 156 curve that can be reconstructed from laboratory experiments and natural transmission data. Given 157 the complexities of real-world transmission, factors like mosquito abundance and human 158 interventions are usually simplified out of this approach, leaving behind a scaled (relative) curve 159 for the temperature-dependent component of R0, the basic reproduction number (that is, the per-160 capita growth rate of disease transmission; for a full explanation and equations, see Methods). For 161 this approach, the R0(T) expression denotes suitability for transmission as a function of 162 temperature, scaled between zero and one, derived from a fully-parameterized, life-history explicit, 163 temperature-dependent transmission model of both the vector and pathogen.

FIGREF7.text: 176 found that SRM might substantially reduce malaria transmission in the Indian subcontinent and 177 the Sahel. Relative reductions are also strong in high-elevation areas like the Andes, the Ethiopian 178 highlands, and the Rift Valley, which have been conventionally viewed as the most vulnerable to 179 malaria encroachment in a warming climate, and are also some of the only regions with an 180 identifiable signal of anthropogenic climate change in recent malaria resurgences.181However, we also found that in many tropical regions-including the Amazon basin, Indonesia, 182 west and central Africa, and the southeast and Atlantic coasts of Africa-solar geoengineering in 183 either the G3 or GLENS scenario could, by stabilizing temperatures at colder levels, increase the 184 relative suitability for malaria compared to a future without geoengineering(Figure 2A,B). This 185 is most pronounced in Brazil, Peru, Ecuador, Venezuela and Mozambique, which would all warm 186 under RCP 8.5 so much that they reach a near-zero average suitability for malaria. This reduction 187 is projected to be reversed by SRM in the GLENS scenario, which returns these countries to nearly-188 optimal temperatures for malaria by cooling them up to one degree relative to present day 189 temperatures (30).

FIGREF8.text: , we compared 2070 scenarios with geoengineering to malaria suitability in the present day 191 (2020), and found that a future with SRM deployment still looks markedly different from the 192 present day(Figure 2C,D). In particular, in the G3 scenario, most of Africa and part of southeast193 Asia experiences much higher suitability for malaria transmission, while reductions are projected 194 in most of Latin America. In contrast, most of the tropics become less suitable for malaria in the 195 GLENS scenario compared to the present day, especially the Indian subcontinent, but the Americas 196 experience some elevated risk, as does a hotspot in southeast Asia. 197 Seasonality and population at risk 198 To explore these patterns further, we identified the outer bounds of transmission from the R0(T) 199 curves (that is, Tmin and Tmax). For each first year of the decade, from 2020 to 2070, we evaluated 200 whether each day of the year fit within the bounds of transmission (Tmin ≤ T ≤ Tmax), and totaled the 201 number of full days that would be conducive to malaria transmission. Using these maps, we split 202 the tropics into regions where malaria transmission risk was unstable (at least one month was 203 conducive for transmission) or stable (at least half the year). Categories similar to these have been 204 previously used to roughly identify where conditions could permit epidemic and endemic 205 transmission, respectively (20,33,34). Both categories carry risk; today, holoendemic (year-round 206 transmission) malaria places a high burden on children and pregnant women in many hotspots, but 207 episodic malaria epidemics in areas with lower immunity can exhibit high case fatality rates (35).

FIGREF10.text: 229 exception to this global pattern (similar risk with and without geoengineering) is in Africa, where 230 cooler temperatures under G3 are projected to lead to large shifts in population at risk (Extended 231 Data Figure 1). Specifically, in east Africa, compared to RCP 4.5, geoengineering reduces the 232 expansion of the duration of the transmission season, and thereby leads to a smaller increase in 233 population experiencing stable transmission throughout the century. The opposite pattern is 234 projected for west Africa, where geoengineering is projected to elevate stable transmission risk for 235 roughly 100 million people compared to the baseline scenario. 236 A larger geoengineering deployment to stabilize planetary temperatures at 2020 levels despite high 237 emissions (the GLENS scenario) would nullify a projected reduction of almost one billion more 238 people at the highest risk of malaria in 2070, compared to climate change without geoengineering 239 (RCP 8.5)

FIGREF11.text: 240 falciparum malaria, the most striking effect is on west Africa: whereas extreme warming begins 241 to decrease malaria endemicity mid-century, avoiding warming through solar geoengineering 242 allows populations at risk to continue growing, leading to a difference of nearly 200 million people 243 by late in the century (Extended Data Figure 3). In both south and southeast Asia, RCP 8.5 leads 244 to massive decreases in stable risk (Extended Data Figure 4). However, averting warming in the 245 GLENS scenario almost entirely nullifies these declines, with a higher population at risk from 246 stable transmission by roughly 200 million people in each region. In east Asia and tropical Latin 247America, much smaller increases in stable risk are projected due to geoengineering.

FIGREF13.text: proposed geoengineering scenarios we consider are hypotheticals, our results show 262 that geoengineering may not always have desirable health outcomes. Our simulations indicate that 263 proposed geoengineering schemes could lead to local benefits in east Africa, but also large adverse 264 impacts on west Africa and southern Asia. Totaled across regions, the geoengineering scenarios265    we examined have at best a neutral but patchwork effect on total malaria risk, and at worst could 266 elevate malaria risk relative to climate change without geoengineering. As such, these scenarios267 illustrate that solar geoengineering could have adverse impacts on health in cases where the burden 268 of infectious diseases lacks a monotonic, positive relationship with warming temperatures. If those 269 diseases are a priority for developing countries' climate policy (as malaria still is in much of the 270 world), we suggest that current proposals for geoengineering might therefore be mismatched to 271 the aim of reducing climate injustice in the health sector. Recent studies based on overshoot 272 scenarios, in which less SRM would be deployed (e.g., (36)), could plausibly lessen the dangers 273 described here, and need to be evaluated with regard to malaria and other health risks. 274 For health risks with nonlinear responses to temperature (such as vector-borne diseases), this is 275 likely to be a persistent problem, even for geoengineering deployments that only partially offset 276 global warming. Despite their importance, these health risks are comparatively understudied, in 277 part because climate change impact detection and attribution is more difficult than when evaluating 278 other, more direct health impacts of climate (e.g., heat-related deaths), and projections often follow 279 less intuitive patterns. While reduced warming is likely to have some benefits in places where280

FIGREF14.text: 286 nearly impossible to optimize across all possible or even all major health burdens, including the 287 hundreds of infectious diseases with poorly-understood, non-linear relationships with warming 288 and other climate variables. 289 This challenge is particularly pronounced given the difficulty of impact assessment for infectious 290 diseases. For example, in this study, we used a relatively simple approach to measuring population 291 at risk and temperature-sensitive transmission. More advanced models that incorporate human-292 vector transmission dynamics, and other climate variables like precipitation, have become 293 increasingly accessible (37); accounting for these variables will only complicate the non-linear 294 relationships between health outcomes and climate geoengineering interventions. Similarly, the 295 relative priority of malaria is dependent not just on climate change scenarios, but also planetary 296 health scenarios (38). For example, before the COVID-19 pandemic, malaria elimination within a 297 generation was considered plausible, both in terms of epidemiological likelihood and political

FIGREF15.text: 308 climate change policy, including in geoengineering conversations (42). This matters particularly 309 for the health sector, where tradeoffs may emerge between the priorities of developing countries 310 and of those with the greatest influence in climate policy. Vector-borne diseases are largely 311 projected to shift from the tropics to higher latitudes, especially into more affluent countries with 312 stronger health systems, and that increased risk has dominated conversations about their climate 313 change impacts as compared to trends in the rest of the world. For example, dengue incursion into 314 Europe regularly gathers almost as much attention as the record-setting 2019 dengue epidemics in 315 at least a dozen developing countries. Previous work in this space has cautioned against framing 316 the health impacts of climate change around the encroachment of tropical diseases into less 317 vulnerable Global North countries, but this remains a dominant talking point for climate change 318 impacts on vector-borne disease. 319 Debate around solar geoengineering could readily fall into similar traps. While geoengineering 320 might reverse the incursion of tropical diseases into higher latitudes, this framing is oblivious to 321 the reality that the global burden of infectious disease falls disproportionately on the same poorer, 322 tropical and subtropical countries (including small island states) that are syndemically vulnerable 323 to future climate impacts and climate injustice. Framing geoengineering around the health impacts 324 of the "climate emergency" may therefore be undesirable (43), compared to a strategy that 325 meaningfully engages developing countries in terms of their priorities, and develops a 326 comprehensive evidence base of how proposed scenarios will redistribute disease burden between 327 regions. In solar geoengineering research, this means that global involvement in science must not 328 stop with climate modeling; countries' priorities for climate policy, and developing country voices, 329 must be reflected by the impact assessment literature. Only with that greater involvement can the 330 "design problem" of geoengineering meaningfully reflect its impacts on the people most 331 vulnerable to anthropogenic climate change. At the same time, for the health sector -which has a 332 high stake in global climate politics, but little power over it, especially in the regions most 333 vulnerable to epidemics -these kinds of projections will be an important step towards preparing 334 for an uncertain global future.

FIGREF17.text: GeoMIP) (31) simulates the injection of aerosols into the stratosphere from the equator, starting 340 in 2020 and increasing injection amounts gradually in order to keep global average temperature 341 nearly constant at 2020 levels, despite increasing greenhouse gas concentrations consistent with 342 the moderate mitigation RCP4.5 scenario. The G3 scenario terminates geoengineering in 2070. 343 Therefore, we compared malaria risk in the G3 scenario to climate change in RCP4.5 between 344 2020 and 2070. The Geoengineering Large Ensemble (GLENS) (32) starts injection of 345 stratospheric aerosols at four locations (30°N, 30°S, 15°N and 15°S) in 2020 in order keep average 346 global temperature constant at 2020 levels, despite increasing greenhouse gas concentrations from 347 RCP8.5, a no mitigation scenario. We compared malaria risk in the GLENS scenario to RCP8.5 348 between 2020 and 2070. 349 We used projections of near-surface daily air temperature and monthly precipitation from the 350 HadGEM2-ES model for both the G3 and RCP4.5 scenarios and from the CESMI(WACCM) 351 model for GLENS and RCP8.5. We selected these climate models and scenarios in part because, 352 while earlier geoengineering simulations merely turned down the solar constant, both models in 353 this study simulated the more "realistic" creation of a stratospheric aerosol layer. Three ensemble 354 members (that is, simulations beginning with slightly different initial conditions) were used from 355 each climate model for each scenario in order to account for natural variability of the climate 356 system, allowing evaluation of the extent to which differences in malaria risk between scenarios 357 with and without geoengineering are forced or random. (Because both the G3 and GLENS358 scenarios are accompanied by only three natural climate runs, we paired them with the first three 359 ensemble runs generated by each geoengineering simulation, for a balanced study design.) All 360 climate variables were regridded to one-degree spatial resolution using bilinear interpolation. 361 Malaria Transmission Models 362 Because mosquitoes are ectothermic, mosquito-borne diseases are incredibly temperature-363 sensitive, and their global distribution and burden is shaped by the underlying landscape of climate. 364 The transmission of mosquito-borne disease is usually depicted as a unimodal response to 365 temperature, with an optimum temperature for transmission bounded above and below by critical 366 limits. When ambient temperature is within those bounds, vectors are considered competent 367 enough to transmit diseases. "Transmission" is most readily depicted as a relative basic 368 reproduction number R0(T), which can be rescaled between zero and one for convenience, and is 369 used to identify the minimum, optimum, and maximum temperature for transmission. This can be 370 parameterized with a combination of seven ecological traits (biting rate a, vector competence c, 371 parasite development rate PDR, mosquito development rate D, egg-to-adult mosquito survival s, 372 adult mosquito mortality µ, and egg laying per day E), using a set of formulas based on the 373 canonical Ross-Macdonald model of malaria transmission. By fitting nonlinear curves to each of 374 the seven traits, a total transmission R0(T) can be derived:

FIGREF18.text: populations at risk by dividing the world into a set of regions modified from the 426 Global Burden of Disease study regions (11,13,48), and estimated the population at risk from 427 falciparum and vivax malaria based on the thermal bounds and precipitation cutoffs explained 428 above. These regions have previously been used for impact assessment models (11,13), but we 429 have made two slight adjustments that primarily reflect the global status of malaria elimination 430 and burden. Given that the Caribbean has eliminated malaria, we reassigned Belize to Latin 431 America (Central), and reassigned Guyana, French Guiana, and Suriname to Latin America 432 (Tropical). Similarly, given the high burden of malaria on the entire island of New Guinea, which 433 is split by the boundary between Indonesia and Papua New Guinea, we regrouped Papua New 434 Guinea with Asia (Southeast).

FIGREF19.text: We paired malaria regions with the dominant form of malaria in each. In Africa, the more severe436 P. falciparum is the dominant form of malaria, while P. vivax is endemic to South America, 437 southern Asia, and-though rarer than falciparum-parts of east Africa. We therefore modeled 438 falciparum risk in four regions of Africa (West, East, Central, & Southern), and modeled vivax 439 risk in six regions of Asia (East, South, and Southeast) and Latin America (Central, Tropical, and440

FIGREF20.text: 445 identifies more and less plausible combinations of global development strategies and greenhouse 446 gas emissions reductions (49). Given that RCP and geoengineering scenarios were paired, we 447 chose to keep consistent SSPs between baselines and geoengineering scenarios. In practice, this 448 led to two experiments: (1) RCP4.5 (some mitigation) paired with SSP2 versus G3 paired with 449 SSP2; and (2) RCP8.5 (minimal mitigation) paired with SSP5 versus GLENS paired with SSP5.

FIGREF21.text: each climate-SSP pairing we used three climate model runs. SSP data were taken from the 451 SEDAC Global One-Eighth Degree Population Projection Grids (50), which include urban and 452 rural population projections for each decade between 2010 and 2100.

TABREF0.text: fever by up to one billion people (11,12), and could plausibly expose a similar or greater number of people to Zika virus if waning population immunity permits another global epidemic (13). In Africa, deaths from yellow fever could increase by 10% to 25%, depending on warming trajectories and vaccination program coverage (14). But none of these viral infections have a remotely comparable burden to malaria. For comparison, dengue fever is the highest-burden mosquito-borne virus (15). In 2019, the Americas experienced a world-record 3 million reported cases, including at least 1,200 reported deaths. In contrast, the global annual case total of malaria exceeds 200 million, with at least 400,000 deaths almost all caused by the parasite Plasmodium falciparum. Malaria remains the sixth largest cause of death in low income countries; though highly effective control efforts have reduced falciparum malaria prevalence in Africa by half since the turn of the century (16)-making elimination plausible within a generation (17) -the impacts of COVID-19 might jeopardize this progress(18,19). Most available evidence suggests that climate change will favor the expansion of falciparum malaria into southern Africa and highelevation regions of east Africa, and possibly reduce transmission in central Africa and the west African Sahel, though less certainty exists on the second point (20-25).Comparatively less attention has been paid to Plasmodium vivax malaria, which is responsible for at most 1% of the total global deaths from malaria, but is responsible for 42% of all malaria cases outside Africa, and is likely underreported globally (26). In the Americas, P. vivax is predominant 100 in most malaria reporting countries, and cases are increasing, including co-infections, according101 to recent work (27). The collapse of Venezuela's economy, and resulting migration of populations 102 in its wake, following a rapid rise in malaria cases reported from Venezuela, have led to 103 resurgences of both strains of malaria in elimination regions in Latin America (28). This signals 104 that suitable conditions can give rise to re-seeding and re-establishment of transmission in the 105 absence of strict surveillance and control programs (perhaps a bellwether for the importance of climate shifts). The prospect of encroachment of vivax malaria into new areas is particularly troubling, as elimination strategies have largely focused on P. falciparum, and basic surveillance may therefore overlook the need to anticipate P. vivax, or may simply not have the required testing capacity. Despite these looming risks, vivax malaria is often under-represented in climate work, as comparatively less has been known about its ecology.Two aspects of malaria transmission make this disease a high priority for risk assessment in solar 112 geoengineering research. First, malaria's burden is measurable enough that it impacts economic 113 growth and population-level mortality; if geoengineering is intended to reduce the health risks of climate change in developing countries, perhaps one of the greatest reductions could be 115 experienced through impacts on malaria. Second, for a pathogen with a mostly tropical burden, malaria is unusually adapted to cooler temperatures, with peak transmission around 25°C (29). It has been hypothesized that malaria transmission could be inadvertently facilitated by SRM (8), especially given that SRM may cool tropical latitudes relatively more (30). Consequently, when compared to global warming without solar geoengineering, a geoengineering deployment might

TABREF1.text: The shape of that curve varies data, with an optimal temperature around 25°C. Comparatively less is known about P. vivax, the less severe form endemic to southern Asia and the Americas; previously, this pathogen reached much higher latitudes, and has been conventionally viewed as more cold-adapted than P.that the lower critical temperatures of P. vivax may in fact be largely driven by the An. stephensi mosquito in south Asia (44); comparatively less is known about P. vivax in the Americas.To map malaria, we used an approach originally developed over the last decade (22,45), which identifies areas suitable for malaria transmission based primarily on temperature. Following (45), we used daily gridded climate data and mapped the number of days in each pixel that were fully within the thermal bounds of transmission based on R0(T). Adapting the approach used by previous studies, we masked out deserts based on the most commonly used definition in the geosciences 401 (250 mm annual precipitation or less). This step accounts for the possibility that some areas are too arid for mosquitoes to complete their reproductive cycle in some areas (though some species, like An. stephensi, are container breeders like the yellow fever mosquito Aedes aegypti, and may persist in areas with the help of human structures). Beyond this masking step, the presence or absence of Anopheles vectors only minimally limit this approach; roughly a hundred species of Anopheles are capable of transmitting malaria on every inhabited continent, and competent vectors occurred throughout the regions we were considering (46). However, it remains possible that mosquito range shifts-or possible coevolution between mosquitoes and parasites in the futurecould change the reliability of this first order proxy, as could the expansion of P. vivax and An. stephensi mosquitoes in eastern Africa, or any other state shifts in malaria control.To reflect differences in vector-pathogen systems across landscapes, we used three separate transmission models by region (see below). In sub-Saharan Africa, we used the canonical estimates of Plasmodium falciparum transmission by An. gambiae (17 to 34°C), based on (29). Several 414 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.(which was not certified by peer review)The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted October 25, 2020. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.10.21.20217257 doi: medRxiv preprint studies since have proposed adjustments to these limits, based on further mathematical modifications of the R0(T) model (e.g., the inclusion of daily thermal variation through an integral process), but we chose to stay with these estimates as the most similar to the experimental limits that have been observed for transmission (which has been seen as low as 16°C). For Plasmodium vivax in southern Asia, we used a more recent estimate by (44), which assumes that transmission 419 by An. stephensi occurs between 15.7°C and 32.5°C. For P. vivax in the Americas, where at least ten Anopheles vectors have been identified as transmitters of malaria (47), as there is little published thermal ecology for individual vector-parasite pairs, we assumed based that local vectors were comparable to An. gambiae in their thermal ecology, and that the bounds of vivax transmission were 19.4°C to 31.6°C.

back_matter.text: into two strata of risk: unstable or epidemic risk (over 30 days and under 180 days, or 1-6 months 459 of the year), and stable or endemic risk (over 6 months of the year). These classifications are 460 adapted from prior work that has stratified based on monthly temperature cutoffs, but have been 461 adapted to using daily-level climate data. The split can be thought of as indicative of a first-order 462 stratification of burden: most of the burden of malaria, especially mortality, is clustered in places 463 where malaria is endemic or hyperendemic. However, epidemics can be particularly severe in 464 places where malaria is rare, and population immunity is therefore lower (e.g., high-elevation 465 communities in east Africa, or near-elimination communities in Latin America).
